Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Socioeconomic Inequalities in Technology Use and Health Lifestyles among Children and Youth.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will analyze the use of technologies by children and teenagers in the mobile internet era. The focus is how technology use is situated within the interaction of children's lives and families, and how social class plays into these processes. With technologies changing rapidly, research on young people's technology use have lagged. The study will contribute to knowledge in several areas. First, the project will provide new information about the type, frequency, and context of technology use among children and youth. Second, investigators will build upon the emerging body of evidence and theory on children's health lifestyles by integrating technology use as a health behavior. Third, investigators will consider children's and parents' negotiations, practices, and emerging understandings around technology use. Understanding children's technology use as it relates to other behavior is important for improving the longer-term development, health, and well-being of children. This is particularly important for marginalized populations--racial/ethnic minorities, children of immigrants, and children living in poverty. Student training is central to the project, with students heavily involved in analysis, dissemination of findings, theoretical development, and integration of quantitative and qualitative results.

Relatively little is known about children's technology use in the mobile technology era or about how current patterns of technology use relate to other aspects of health lifestyles, such as physical activity or socializing with peers, in early life. This project will address three research questions. First, how does social class currently shape children's technology use and its role in their health lifestyles? Second, how does social class influence parents' perceptions of emerging technologies and their strategies for structuring and negotiating children's access to and use of these technologies? Third, do family negotiations and practices around technology use help to explain socioeconomic variation in children's technology use? This project will draw on two new data sources to provide breadth and depth in understanding the relationship between social class and contemporary children's technology use and processes underlying it. The 2014 Child Development Supplement (CDS) of the Panel Study of Income Dynamics collected survey and time diary data from a US-representative sample ages 0-17. The 2016 Children's Health Lifestyles study provides multimethod qualitative data on families with elementary-aged children. The observational data permit a fuller understanding of the social settings of technology use, and interview and focus groups illuminate perceptions of and negotiations around it.

POR.DRECONTENT:
University of Michigan
Collaborative Research: Inequalities in Technology Use and Health Lifestyles among Children and Youth

Young people’s use of technologies has changed rapidly, and scientific investigations and theoretical development have lagged behind. Because technology use is a largely sedentary health behavior but it can develop useful skills for science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields, its implications are complicated for parents who want to ensure their children’s long-term well-being. This project investigated how families react when socioeconomic and health goals for their children conflict, as well as how family social class and other inequalities played into these processes. Building on and integrating previous knowledge about health disparities, social class, and parenting, this project generated new knowledge to help understand changes in children’s, adolescents’, and young adults’ technology use. It examined how technology use relates to other health behaviors and health lifestyles, as well as how the COVID-19 pandemic shaped technology use and the family dynamics and social inequalities around it.

 

Little is known about children’s technology use in the mobile technology era. We drew on two new data sources to understand contemporary young people’s technology use, its relationship to other health behaviors, how parents manage their children’s technology use, and related social inequalities. The 2014 Child Development Supplement (CDS) of the Panel Study of Income Dynamics collected survey and time diary data from a US nationally representative sample of children ages 0-17. These data allowed comparison with young people in 1997 and 2002 cohort of children to investigate changes over time in technology use and its relationship to other health behaviors and to social inequalities. The 2015-2020 Children’s Health Lifestyles study conducted up to four waves of in-depth interviews with parents and teenagers as the teens grew from elementary age into high school.

 

We found that children’s time spent using technology increased by one third in early childhood and one quarter in middle childhood compared to 1997, and by 16 percent in adolescence compared to 2002. By the mid-2010s, weekly average technology time stood at 24 hours in early childhood, 23 hours in middle childhood, and 33 hours in adolescence. In terms of social class differences, children age 12 and under with college-educated parents consistently used technology for activities such as television viewing, video game play, and social media use for fewer hours per week compared to peers whose parents had a high school diploma. Young adults’ time spent using technology was only weakly related to their technology use in adolescence and was also shaped by current social contexts. Children’s gender emerged as surprisingly important for understanding how parents make sense of and negotiate their children’s technology use. Boys were viewed as being at particular risk for addiction to technology but were taught to be agentic and involved in technology use, as it was viewed as important for their future lives. For girls, in contrast, technology was seen as highly threatening for their physical safety and peer relationships and problematic for their social bonds with family members. Parents were more likely to limit technology for girls and struggle to understand how to teach girls to manage technology now and as they prepare for their futures.

 

Student training and education were integral parts of this project. The students—most coming from underrepresented groups in science—received training and mentoring that otherwise would not have been available. Several of the student team members will pursue careers as professors or in public health and medicine.

 

This project contextualized technology use within overarching health lifestyles and childhood activities, which is promising for informing social policy because it moves beyond an approach that strips a single behavior of its social context in isolating its effects on people. This broader lens for understanding the social embeddedness of children’s technology use can inform future policy efforts and help researchers understand the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic.
